questions.text: Compound that joins glycolysis with glycogenesis & glycogenolysis:
questions.solution:

questions.text: Anticoagulant used to estimate glucose from a sample sent from PHC is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Potassium oxalate + NaF

To diagnose and monitor the treatment efficiency, fasting plasma glucose and 2nd hour plasma glucose levels, oral Glucose Tolerance Test (GTT) and HbA1c are commonly estimated in the laboratory. Vacutainer used for collecting blood sample for Fasting Blood Glucose (FBS) and Post Prandial Blood Sugar (PPBS), and GTT contains NaF as additive and potassium oxalate as the anticoagulant. American Diabetes Association (ADA) and World Health Organisation (WHO) recommended that criteria for diagnosis of diabetes mellitus should be HbA1c level equal or above 6.5%

questions.text: After overnight fasting, levels of Glucose transporters are reduced in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Adipocytes

The effect of insulin to acutely stimulate glucose uptake into muscle and adipose tissue is essential for normal glucose homeostasis. The GLUT4 glucose transporter is a major mediator of this action, and insulin recruits GLUT4 from an intracellular pool to the plasma membrane.

questions.text: During gluconeogenesis reducing equivalents from mitochondria to cytosol are transported by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Malate

The cellular NAD+/NADH ratio plays a crucial role in regulating metabolic activity. Cellular oxidation reactions require the net transfer of electrons to an electron acceptor, such as NAD+, to yield NADH. The electrons of NADH are consumed in the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC) to drive ATP synthesis, coupling cellular oxidation reactions to oxidative phosphorylation. Since cytosolic NADH cannot cross the inner mitochondrial membrane directly, reducing equivalents from NADH are indirectly transported to the mitochondrial matrix via the malate-aspartate shuttle (MAS) or directly to the ETC via the glycerol 3-phosphate shuttle. Both shuttles regenerate cytosolic NAD+ to sustain cytosolic oxidative pathways such as glycolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is best known location for cardiolipin within the cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inner mitochondrial membrane

As cardiolipin is the characteristic lipid component of mitochondria, its function in this organelle is clearly crucial in all tissues and organisms. Mitochondria have unique double membranes, the outer and inner mitochondrial membranes, and these enclose two aqueous compartments, the intermembrane space and the matrix. It is located mainly on the inner membrane of mitochondria, where it interacts strongly to control many integral membrane proteins in a manner that is determined by its physical and structural properties, but it also regulates endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondrial contact sites. In summary, it is involved in the biogenesis, morphology and stability of mitochondrial cristae, in mitochondrial quality control and dynamics through fission and fusion, and in innumerable aspects of mitochondrial metabolism. Bioenergetic processes, such as the tricarboxylic acid cycle and β oxidation of fatty acids, are performed within the matrix.

questions.text: What is the substrate for the physiologically irreversible reaction in the Kreb’S & Citric acid cycle-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alpha ketoglutarate

The 3 irreversible reactions in the TCA :
1. Citrate synthase – acetylcoA + OAA
2. Alpha Ketoglutarate DH – Alpha ketoglutarate

questions.text: A neonate few days after birth suddenly becomes lethargic and starts refusing breast feeding and vomits during forced breast feeding. Mother also states that the baby had developed diarrhea on the 3rd day. Clinical examination reveals that the child has presented with oil drop cataract. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Classical Galactosemia

The diagnosis of classic galactosemia and clinical variant galactosemia is established by detection of elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate concentration, reduced erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) enzyme activity, and/or biallelic pathogenic variants in GALT.
In classic galactosemia, erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate is usually >10 mg/dL and erythrocyte GALT enzyme activity is absent or barely detectable. In clinical variant galactosemia, erythrocyte GALT enzyme activity is close to or above 1% of control values but probably never >10%-15%. However, in African Americans with clinical variant galactosemia, the erythrocyte GALT enzyme activity may be absent or barely detectable but is often much higher in liver and in intestinal tissue (e.g., 10% of control values).

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation is catalyzed by :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SuccinylCoA Thiokinase

The only step where substrate-level phosphorylation happens in the Krebs cycle is:

A phosphoryl group is transferred from succinyl-CoA to GDP, forming succinate and GTP. This step is catalyzed by the enzyme succinyl-CoA synthetase, producing 2 ATPs per glucose molecule (since the cycle runs twice and two pyruvate molecules enter the Krebs cycle).

• 2 Succinyl-CoA + 2 GDP → 2 Succinate +2 GTP

questions.text: Which vitamin is involved in Redox reactions:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Riboflavin

Riboflavin plays a central role in controlling the 2-electron acceptor/donor and 1-electron acceptor/donor complexes within the electron transport chain. Embedded within the inner membrane of the mitochondria are 4 complexes (numbered I–IV) that consist of several different electron carriers. Complexes I and II contain flavoprotein reductases (dehydrogenases) and electron transferring flavoproteins, whereas complexes III and IV are composed of a ubiquinone (coenzyme Q10) component and a variety of cytochromes, respectively. Studies show that abnormalities within complex I correlate highly with mitochondrial disorders manifesting predominantly as human neurodegenerative diseases.

questions.text: The specialized mammalian tissue/organ in which fuel oxidation serves not to produce ATP but to generate heat is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Brown adipose tissue

Adipose tissue with the unique capacity to produce heat by consuming circulatory and intracellularly stored substrates is commonly known as brown adipose tissue (BAT). This adipose tissue is labelled as “brown” due to its characteristic brownish macroscopic appearance. This unique tissue morphology is due to the dissimilar cellular composition of brown adipocytes compared to white adipocytes.

The ability of brown adipocytes to produce heat arises from the presence of a large number of mitochondria, along with the high expression of uncoupling protein-1 (UCP1).

questions.text: A child who has accompanied his father to a fish farming area in his hometown accidentally ingests a white odourless compound. The person was under some medication and post meal he developed toxicity of the drug. Which of the following toxin is most like to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rotenone

Rotenone halts this process by inhibiting the function of a protein cluster known as Complex I, the first step in the electron transport chain. This binding action prevents electrons from being passed along, effectively shutting down the production of ATP.

questions.text: An infant has hepato renomegaly, hypoglycemia hyperlipidemia, acidosis; normal structured glycogen deposition in liver. What is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Von Gerke’s 

Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), or Von Gierke disease, is a rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder that impairs glucose production through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. First described by Dr. Edgar Von Gierke in 1929, GSD I results from mutations affecting glucose-6-phosphatase (G6Pase) activity, leading to excessive glycogen accumulation in the liver and kidneys. This disruption causes severe fasting hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. The primary subtypes of GSD I are GSD Ia, caused by G6Pase deficiency due to mutations in the G6PC gene, and GSD Ib, resulting from mutations in the SLC37A4 gene, which affects glucose-6-phosphate translocase (G6PT). While GSD Ia primarily affects glucose metabolism, GSD Ib also leads to neutropenia and increased infection risk due to impaired neutrophil function.

questions.text: Which among the following is not seen in fasting hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glucagon excess

Glucagon excess contributes to hyperglycaemia whereas reduced glucagon response to insulin-induced hypoglycaemia promotes severe hypoglycaemia. It is expected that drugs that are able to reduce glucagon secretion in concert with strategies directed to recover glucagon secretion to hypoglycaemia might contribute to improve the overall glycaemic control in diabetes.

questions.text: An infant is being assessed for hypotonia, seizures, and neurodevelopmental delay. Clinical examination reveals facial deformities, hyporeflexia, and hepatomegaly. A congenital disorder affecting extramitochondrial lipid metabolism is suspected. Which of the following processes is impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The clinical vignette is suggestive of Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome in which H202-mediated peroxisomal beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) is impaired.

Beta-oxidation in peroxisome is differentiated from that occurring in mitochondria by the formation of H2O2.
Beta-oxidation of fatty acid in peroxisomes is not coupled to ATP synthesis. The high-potential electrons are transferred to O2, which yields H2O2 (instead of FADH2). The enzyme catalase, found exclusively in peroxisomes, converts the hydrogen peroxide to end products water and oxygen.

Zellweger syndrome is a rare inherited disorder characterized by the absence of peroxisomal enzymes in all tissues leading to the accumulation of C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue. The clinical manifestation of Zellweger syndrome includes:

• Facial deformities resembling Down syndrome (Mongoloid facies, Hypertelorism, Frontal bossing, Upslanting palpebral fissure)

• Brush field spots

• Hypotonia and hyporeflexia

• Seizures

Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is expressed in all tissues and is necessary to maintain the oxidant stress capacity of cells. G6PD is a cytoplasmic enzyme involved in the hexose monophosphate pathway and protects erythrocytes against oxidative damage by producing NADPH.

Malic enzyme (ME) is a key enzyme regulating the lipid accumulation process in oleaginous microorganisms. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of L -malate to pyruvate and CO 2 with concomitant reduction of NADP + to NADPH, supplying the reducing power for fatty acid biosynthesis.

questions.text: PFK 1 inhibitor-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Citrate

PFK1 is a regulated step in glycolysis that is bound to inhibitors and activators. High levels of ATP allosterically inhibit PFK1, but AMP reverses the inhibitory action of ATP. Therefore, the activity of the enzyme increases when the cellular ATP/AMP ratio is lowered. Citrate is also an allosteric inhibitor for PFK1.

questions.text: 65-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 84 kg, BMI is 25 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 95 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration of 19.3 mol/L (N=5-15). Serum lipid concentrations are within the reference range. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cystathionine beta synthase

CBS deficiency is caused by mutations in the CBS gene, which provides instructions for producing the enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the metabolism of the amino acid homocysteine. When the CBS enzyme is deficient or dysfunctional due to genetic mutations, homocysteine accumulates in the blood, leading to the various symptoms associated with the disorder. CBS deficiency follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, meaning that an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the condition.

questions.text: Molecular change in Lysosomal storage disorder is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mutation of genes encoding lysosomal hydrolases

Lysosomal storage diseases or disorders (LSDs) are rare genetic conditions that cause a buildup of toxic materials in your body’s cells. People with LSDs lack certain enzymes or a substance that helps the enzyme work (enzyme activator or modifier). Without functioning enzymes, your body can’t break down fats and sugars and other substances. If those build up in your body, they can be harmful.

questions.text: Apo B48 and apo B100 are expressed as two different apo-proteins because of difference in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RNA editing

Apolipoprotein B (apo B) circulates in two distinct forms referred to as apo B100 and apo B48. Apo B48 is colinear with the amino-terminal half of apo B100 and arises as a result of a post-transcriptional modification, termed apo B mRNA editing. This process changes a single cytidine nucleotide in apo B100 mRNA thereby altering a CAA codon, encoding glutamine in apo B100, to a UAA codon, which specifies an in-frame stop codon in apo B48.

questions.text: Which of the following is an activator of LCAT-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Apo AI

Lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) is an enzyme that first hydrolyzes the sn-2 position of phospholipids, preferentially a diacylphosphocholine, and then transfers the fatty acid to cholesterol to yield a cholesteryl ester. HDL ApoA-I is the principal catalytic activator for LCAT. Activity of LCAT on nascent or lipid-poor HDL particles composed of phospholipid, cholesterol and ApoA-I allows the maturation of HDL particles into lipid-rich spherical particles that contain a core of cholesteryl ester surrounded by phospholipid and ApoA-I on the surface.

questions.text: Beta-Oxidation in peroxisome is deficiency of which of the following enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

H2O2 formed

VLCFAs enter the peroxisome in the form of -CoA, start the β-oxidation from the first oxidation, undergo hydrolysis, begin the second oxidation, undergo thiolysis, and remove two C atoms. If VLCFAs are still present, they will enter the cycle again until the number of carbon chains is less than 18, after which the products will enter the mitochondria to continue metabolism.  In peroxisomes, the high-energy electrons stored in FADH2 are directly transferred from O2 to H2O2, and subsequently decomposed into H2O and O2

choices.text: Increase in glucagon/insulin ratio, increased CAMP and increased blood glucose

questions.text: Starvation and diabetes mellitus can lead onto ketoacidosis which of the following features is in favor of ketoacidosis due to diabetes mellitus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in glucagon/insulin ratio, increased CAMP and increased blood glucose

Defects in insulin secretion and aggravation of insulin resistance are considered the primary factors affecting diabetes development and progression. However, apart from insulin itself, various other factors may also affect glucose regulation in diabetes . One of these factors may be the dysregulation of glucagon upon pancreatic α-cell dysfunction . By enhancing gluconeogenesis in the liver, glucagon levels are elevated upon fasting to prevent hypoglycemia . The secretory mechanism of glucagon from α-cells has been proposed to be regulated by insulin concentrations from β-cells, which are located closely to α-cells . From a theoretical view, when insulin secretion increases after meals, glucagon secretion must be suppressed . However, this mechanism appears to be dysregulated in diabetic patients who show relatively higher postprandial glucagon levels than normal subjects .

questions.text: An immunoglobulin molecule represents the following level of organized protein structure:

Immunoglobulins, also known as antibodies, have well developed quaternary structure are special types of glycoprotein molecules that are secreted by well-differentiated B cells, called plasma cells. Antibodies specifically react with the antigens which stimulated their production. They are released from lymph nodes and spleen into the blood where they serve as the effector of humoral immunity.

questions.text: Km increased but Vmax same enzyme is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Competitive

Non-competitive inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition where the inhibitor reduces the activity of the enzyme and binds equally well to the enzyme regardless of whether it has already bound the substrate

These are structurally similar to substrates and hence competes with substrate to bind at active site of enzyme (cannot bind to enzyme substrate complex). Increasing the substrate can overcome inhibition as overall efficacy of enzyme is not affected (more substrate is needed to achieve 1/2 Vmax, i.e. Km increases).

questions.text: True about enzyme specificity:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• The specificity of an enzyme refers to the selectivity of an enzyme to a substrate.
• Enzymes have an extremely specific action similar to chemical catalysts they catalyze well-defined reactions.
• The high specificity of the action of enzymes is one of the most important features of living matter.
• The action of enzymes is based on the complementarity of the structure of the substrate and the active center of the enzyme.

questions.text: Reactive oxygen intermediates are released by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

NADPH oxidase

NADPH-oxidase (NOX) is a highly regulated dynamic complex comprising membrane and cytosolic proteins and is the major source of nonmitochondrial cellular reactive oxygen species (ROS). The ROS generated by NADPH oxidases have crucial roles in various physiological processes, including innate immunity, modulation of redox-dependent signalling cascades, and as cofactors in the production of hormones.
NOX enzymes are a family of transmembrane proteins comprising seven members (NOX1-NOX5 and DUOX1 and DUOX2), each with a specific tissue distribution and activation mechanism. They catalyze the reduction of molecular oxygen to superoxide anion, which in turn reacts quickly to generate other ROS, such as hydrogen peroxide. Although basic NOX activity is crucial for normal physiology, overshooting activity of NOX enzymes leads to disease

questions.solution: Correct Answer ()

questions.text: Which of the following irreversible steps of gluconeogenesis occurs in the mitochondria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pyruvate to oxaloacetate



The first step of gluconeogenesis occurs in the mitochondria with the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase. 

Gluconeogenesis uses many of the same enzymes as glycolysis, but in the opposite direction since many of these reactions are reversible. However, three steps require bypassing since they are performed by irreversible enzymatic reactions. The first irreversible step requires two reactions, the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase in the mitochondria followed by the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate by PEP carboxykinase in the cytosol. The second irreversible step is the conversion of fructose-1,6-biphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate by fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase in the cytosol. The final step is the dephosphorylation of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose by glucose-6-phosphatase in the endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with no significant medical history comes to you with a urine positive for fructose. He does not have diabetes mellitus. Which enzyme is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient likely has essential fructosuria, which is caused by a deficiency of hepatic fructokinase. 

Essential fructosuria is a benign deficiency in fructose metabolism that presents as a reducing sugar, not glucose, in the serum and urine of an otherwise healthy young adult. The defect is in hepatic fructokinase (ketohexokinase), which catalyzes the formation of fructose-1-phosphate from fructose to trap it in the cell.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought in by his parents to the emergency department for lethargy and vomiting. The patient was fine until this afternoon, when his parents found him in the garage with an unlabeled open bottle containing an odorless liquid. On exam, the patient is not alert or oriented, but is responsive to touch and pain. The patient is afebrile and pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and respirations are 20/min. Which of the following is an antidote for the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This patient’s presentation is consistent with ethylene glycol poisoning, which is treated with either ethanol or fomepizole. 

Children are at risk of ethylene glycol toxicity as ethylene glycol is a sweet, odorless liquid that is commonly found in homes. The ethylene glycol metabolite glycolic acid is toxic to the kidneys. Glycolic acid is eventually metabolized to oxalic acid, which forms calcium oxalate crystals that cause systemic damage. The antidotes for ethylene glycol poisoning include ethanol and fomepizole. Ethanol has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than ethylene glycol and this competitive inhibition slows the production of ethylene glycol metabolites. Fomepizole is also an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase. While fomepizole has fewer side effects than ethanol, it is much more expensive and less readily available.

questions.text: Which of the following heavy metal poisoning replaces zinc to and causes acquired poisoning:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mercury has a strong affinity for sulfhydryl groups and enzymes that normally require zinc as a cofactor. By replacing zinc in these metalloenzymes, mercury disrupts their normal activity, leading to cellular dysfunction and toxicity. This mechanism explains how mercury poisoning causes acquired enzyme deficiencies and widespread systemic effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and a feeling of fullness after meals. She denies alcohol consumption but admits to a sedentary lifestyle, and a diet high in processed foods and sugary beverages. On physical examination, she had hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated liver enzymes, with alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels at 120 U/L (normal range: 7-56 U/L) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels at 90 U/L (normal range: 5-40 U/L). A lipid profile demonstrates elevated triglyceride levels at 300 mg/dL (normal range: <150 mg/dL). questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to her primary care physician complaining of right upper quadrant pain over the last 6 months. Pain is worst after eating and feels like intermittent squeezing. She also admits to lighter colored stools and a feeling of itchiness on her skin. Physical exam demonstrates a positive Murphy's sign. The vitamin level least likely to be affected by this condition is associated with which of the following deficiency syndromes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
  
This patient presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of gallstone cholestasis, which is associated with malabsorption of fat soluble vitamins. The only water soluble vitamin in this list is vitamin C, which causes scurvy when deficient. 

Vitamins are classified into the water soluble and fat soluble classes depending on their relative partition between oil and water layers. The important distinction to be aware of in this case is that fat soluble vitamins (A,D,E,K) require bile mediated fat micelle formation in order to be properly absorbed. Any prolonged episode of cholestasis can therefore cause malabsorption of these vitamins and in time lead to the associated deficiency syndromes that are discussed in the incorrect answers section. 

The key to approaching a question about abdominal pain is first to localize the syndrome to a quadrant of the abdomen. In this case, the pain is in the right upper quadrant and therefore the differential to consider are liver conditions such as hepatitis and gallbladder disease such as cholecystitis, cholestasis, and cholangitis. The combination of postprandial pain and squeezing pain is referred to as colic and is associated with obstruction of a hollow tube such as the bile duct system. This diagnosis is supported by pruritus and light colored stools due to retention of bile acids. There are no infectious symptoms in this case, but it is important to be aware of Charcot's triad of fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice and is highly suggestive of infectious cholangitis

questions.text: Identify the image and its vitamin deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which is the rate-limiting enzyme in beta-oxidation of fatty acids?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with decreased growth, pigmented retinopathy, hemolytic anemia, and peripheral neuropathy. You suspect that these signs are the result of a vitamin deficiency leading to increased fatty acid oxidation. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This patient is exhibiting the signs of vitamin E deficiency. Deficiency of this fat-soluble vitamin is rare, but can be caused by diseases that cause fat malabsorption such as cystic fibrosis (CF) and abetalipoproteinemia. 

Vitamin E deficiency is uncommon due to the abundance of tocopherols in the typical diet--even patients consuming a vegetarian or vegan diet are not at risk for this condition. The typical patient has impaired absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K); conditions that may cause this include pancreatic insufficiency, Crohn and celiac diseases, cystic fibrosis, cirrhosis, cholestatic liver disease, and small bowel bacterial overgrowth. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare recessive genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the microsomal transfer protein (MTP) gene. This loss-of-function mutation in MTP prevents assembly of apoB in the liver and intestine, leading to the absence of circulating apoB-containing lipoproteins such as LDL and VLDL and impaired transport of fat-soluble vitamins.

questions.text: A newborn undergoing the standard screening tests is found to have a positive test for reducing sugars. Further testing is performed and reveals that the patient does not have galactosemia, but rather is given a diagnosis of fructosuria. What levels of enzymatic activity are altered in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In essential fructosuria (EF), the activity of hexokinase is increased while the activity of fructokinase is decreased. Fructosuria yields a false positive on galactosemia/reducing sugar testing. 

Essential fructosuria is an asymptomatic autosomal recessive disease that presents with the incidental finding of fructosuria when looking for reducing substances in the urine. In EF, decreased levels of fructokinase result in hexokinase phosphorylating fructose to fructose-6-phosphate rather than fructose-1-phosphate. The excess fructose-6-phosphate is either degraded by other metabolic pathways or is excreted in the urine as fructose. The feedback loops in these biochemical pathways result in the increase in hexokinase activity and a decrease in fructokinase activity

questions.text: All are true about the hexose monophosphate shunt, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Source of Acetyl CoA

questions.text: Which of the following glycogen storage disorders results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen having fewer a-1,6 branch points and more a-1,4 linked glucose units with longer outer chains?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is required for the only energy-requiring step of fatty acid oxidation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation is catalyzed by the thiokinase enzyme.
In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase or thiokinase catalyses the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acid for oxidation.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for increase in TAG in a patient with Diabetes Mellitus:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

D
